data.title: Friends forever? Sarah Jessica Parker reveals three words that broke Sex and the City's heart
data.meta_description: Sex and the City star Sarah Jessica Parker says she was "heartbroken" over co-star Kim Cattrall's claim that the four actresses had "never been friends".
data.text:
For 94 television episodes spanning almost a decade, the friendship of Carrie, Samantha, Charlotte and Miranda in Sex and the City was set as the highest benchmark for female friendship.

Even when they returned for two feature films - one good, one not so good - it was proof that such friendships were indestructible.

After all, if Sex and the City 2 couldn't kill it, what could?

It turns out just three words did it in.

In an interview with Piers Morgan last year actress Kim Cattrall - who played Samantha - said she and her co-stars had "never been friends", just colleagues.

Speaking overnight on the US talk show Watch What Happens Live, actress Sarah Jessica Parker, who played Carrie, said Cattrall's words left her "heartbroken".

"I found it very upsetting," Parker told host Andy Cohen. "That's not the way I recall our experience. So it's sad."

Parker said she hoped the four women who starred in the hit series were bound in friendship by their "singular experience".

"It was a professional experience but it became personal because it was years and years of our life," Parker said.

To put some context to Cattrall's comments, they were made in the aftermath of confirmation that a third Sex and the City film would not be made.

The media narrative around the film's cancellation was more or less that Cattrall had sunk it by attaching additional demands around her agreement to star in the film.

Unlike many established pop culture franchises which could withstand a recast, Sex and the City is one of those rare properties where actor and character alchemy is key; without all four actresses on board a third film would have been impossible.

Cattrall denied sinking the project in her interview with Morgan.

"To be thought of as some kind of diva is absolutely ridiculous," she said.

She then said this: "We've never been friends. We've been colleagues and in some way, it's a very healthy place to be."

Plans for the third film solidified last year.

Parker had described the planned third film - most likely a final chapter to the larger story - as a "beautiful, funny, heartbreaking, joyful, very relatable script and story".

The series, which ran between 1998 and 2004, was based on the book of the same name by Candace Bushnell, about the friendship of four women living and working in New York.

Parker played journalist Carrie Bradshaw and Cattrall played publicist Samantha Jones; co-stars Kristin Davis and Cynthia Nixon played art dealer Charlotte York and lawyer Miranda Hobbes.

The series was followed by two feature films, Sex and the City (2008) and Sex and the City 2 (2010), as well as a teen-aged prequel television series, The Carrie Diaries.
